article: When I first came to the USA, I made friends with a neighbor who used to live only two blocks away from my street. We used to visit each other and go out together sometimes. This friend taught me a lot about American _ , but in some cases I had to learn the hard way, because we didn't have enough time together for me to learn all about American culture from him.  One day, this friend invited me to a party. It wasn't a(n) _ party, only some kind of informal get-together. Since it was summer, we had a picnic, _ most of his American friends and s were known to me, but there were others I had never met before. It was the most _ party for me when I noticed that everybody was wearing jeans and simple T-shirts for the day, _ I arrived in proper dress with my shoes and hair all fixed for a fancy party. It was hard to explain my shame to the other _ . When one of them turned around and said, "What nice clothes! What's the occasion ?" I felt my _ burning hot. I didn't answer at all. If she knew how bad I already felt, she wouldn't have come near me. But she did. Maybe she didn't ask on purpose to make me feel _ or uncomfortable, but my reaction had to do with the way I already felt. I could have told her I had to go to another party afterward, but I did not want to continue the _ . Many times I thought of going home and _ but I knew they would _ . It would be even worse for me because I knew they would quickly think that I felt out of _ . So I wanted to pretend that I was OK. I have already realized their _ are different from mine, but after I talked to my friend, I was more persuaded that people here are more casual. They care less about formality unless it is a special occasion, like a _ or a very formal invitation.
